I found this of moderate difficulty, a little tougher than expected for a Sunday.  Les Mis is the correct spelling, now and forever ;) It drives me nuts that this foolhardy affectation of using a Z is dug so securely into culture.  It makes no sense visually or vocally or even for economy.  It's just cutesy for cutesy's sake.  So very d_mb.  (And I know the nickname took early in the show's run; an affectation with legs.)

Anyhow, the flyspeck that actually held me up was amine instead of amino.  I didn't know rondel or Lorca either, so that was a fun corner.

Nice challenging Sunday grid.  Thanks.

Nice Little Chat! Thread

Hello, Crossword Friends! Experiment Day 3 — a thread specifically for friendly discussion. Whether you want to share what you enjoyed about today’s puzzle, ask about a clue/theme that stumped you, or just chat about something nice that happened to you today, this is a place for that. I happen to be partial to fun factoids, so bring those too if you have them!

                                       O

clever, it was a bit triggering for me.

When I was in junior high, passing notes was all the rage.  But they were never meant for me.  Some girl would hand me a note in class, and I'd be all grateful and excited until she told me to pass it along to "Steve", who was the good-looking guy that all the girls wanted to pass notes to.

I don't know how many times I fell for this.  And it's made me the bitter, angry man I am today.

The last part may have been a bit of TEENDRAMA.

GOODOH? No good.

I've worked with hundreds of Brits over the decades, never heard any of them say that. "Good show" is old-timey British, but that obviously wasn't correct.

This turned out to be a fun puzzle with a well constructed theme. I’m a sucker for changes of direction and overlapping answers, and this had both, although it also had more three letter fill than I like.  I didn’t get off to a good start, however, because I confidently entered denim for 1A.  That’s devilish!  Luckily for me I immediately started checking 1-5 down and not only saw my mistake but figured out the interlocking answer trick.

As a soccer/football fan I enjoyed seeing Manuel NEUER in the puzzle.  Seeing him roaming outside the box to snuff out attacks and to ignite transition breaks with pinpoint passes always made watching the German national team entertaining.
Difficult and very satisfying.

Let us not waste our time in idle discourse! Let us do something, while we have the chance! It is not every day that we are needed….To all mankind they were addressed, those cries for help still ringing in our ears! But at this place, at this moment of time, all mankind is us, whether we like it or not. Let us make the most of it, before it is too late!

Samuel Beckett, Waiting for [GOODOH]

Nice theme. Got it early from BLUE DENIM and DATA MINED, and found it very useful in helping the solve, given the usual number of unknown proper names to be worked around.
I'd never heard of ICE MILKS, but got it from the crosses; struggled with [Brit's jolly cry of approval], presumably heard on "Downton Abbey"; and entered NAE for [Scot's denial] through the usual gritted teeth. 
But otherwise the vocabulary was familiar and seemed to flow naturally from the clues. Brisker than my usual Sundays.
30 minutes added to my solve time because I didn't know the difference between an ENEMA and an EDEMA 🥴🥴

This was a trick that I don't recall ever seeing before, but the title of the puzzle certainly gave a big hint.  Those of you who don't bother looking at the Sunday titles are doing yourselves a great disservice.

The hint in the title, plus the non-clues for the two-way words, should be enough to figure out what to do.  (Of course, you have to know that when several clues are just a hyphen, that means the theme involves continuing an answer from somewhere adjacent.  One isolated hyphen clue could just mean that the answer is MINUS or something similar.)

And whenever you see a pattern of answers being one letter too long, or something similar, you know where your theme answers will be.  That clinched GOODOH for me, and even though I wasn't really familiar with that expression, it's in all the dictionaries.  

Newcomers have no concept of how obscure answers once were.  That didn't make them better puzzles, just more obscure, so I'm glad they aren't around much anymore.  But names like LORCA and NEUER aren't really obscure.


Several solvers complained about Naticks.  I didn't know ADENOIDAL, but because I saw "swollen glands" in the clue, I was able to figure it out.  

For what it's worth, xwstats.com rated this puzzle HARD, with the median solver 7% slower than average.  That comports well with my experience, which was about 2/3 the time given for the median, but about 10% slower than my Sunday average.

I thought this was a very clever theme — Lewis's semiordnilaps! As Caitlin observed, DENIM by itself is a perfectly fine answer for 1A. But I knew that 1D [Cornrow or challah feature] had to be BRAID and 2D was definitely LORCA. Those answers prompted me to move the DENIM to 5D. It wasn’t until later that I saw how DENIM became MINED. Figuring out the trick there helped with the other theme answer groups. I first became aware of Federico García Lorca from the Leonard Cohen song "Take This Waltz," a loose translation of Lorca's poem "Pequeño vals vienés." The DJ who I listened to was smitten with the song and played it at least once a day for weeks. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wfNOogGqSLA That's Jennifer Warnes coming in around the fourth minute.
If anyone would like an extra puzzle today, check the Archive for March 13, 2020, in honor of March 16, Happy 🐼 Day!

that was super fun!

What I did was ignore that entire corner until WASDEADS at 120A rattled my brain a little more— enough to read up the line at 97D and “verbally react to in awe”, as anyone should.

These moments are why I do puzzles, and this was the most puzzle-solving fun I’ve had in quite a while. So many kudos!!

Now I’m just waiting for a British solver to weigh in on that whole “good oh” thing.

When I was a teenager in high school, my best friend and I learned to write longhand backwards so that when we were passing notes they would be harder to read if they were intercepted.  When someone asked if we had to take our notes into the girls bathroom to read them in the mirror, we sneered (15-year-olds sneer a lot), because all you had to do was turn the page over and hold it up to the light. Voila! (a word we learned early and used a lot—fifteen-year-olds have a tendency to run things into the ground, but Voila was much less tiresome than a lot of our verbal Gymborees).

Fried CALAMARI, ELROY Jetson, frescoes by GIOTTO, and a clever theme. What's not to love? Here's a link to the xwordinfo.com view of the solved puzzle, which makes it clearer to see what's going on with the theme. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/16/2025

The fill is driving me crazy in places. Already in the NW corner RONDEL and EDEMA stumped not just me but also my brilliant wife. I only knew RONDEL as a kind of knife or dagger, and I've never heard of an EDEMA - I wouldn't know how to solve the clued definition in my native tongue, even though my Polish vocabulary is light-years beyond what's average for a native speaker. I managed to come up with LORCA, and thankfully I knew ARSENIO HALL from that comedy with Eddie Murphy, and I recalled having heard of him as a TV host, but that corner of the grid was still just nasty, even with the fun of figuring out the themed entries.

Then in the NE corner I ran into the mysterious PHANGERS...

I'm a bit scared if continuing my solve now, TBH 🤣

Probably I'll remember this grid as brilliantly themed yet made annoying by the fill.

𝙱 𝙻 𝚄 𝙴 𝚖
𝚁   𝙽 𝙳 𝚒
𝙰 𝚁 𝚂 𝙴 𝙽

This made me think the theme required tracing across to just before the “-“ clue, then down three letters, over one, then then back up through the “-“ clue to get BLUEDENim for 1A. Then doing the mirror image from the bottom row gave DATAMENus, which could be [dug through for digital analysis]. 

This set me back a ways, especially when I tried it on the other “-“ clues. But still a fun puzzle, especially once I got straightened out.

Paul’s themes have been fun in every one of his seven Times puzzles.  He's had the knack of showcasing cool language quirks, and for wordplay-loving me, they've hit my pleasure zone and buoyed my day.  

Today, double-duty words, a semordnilap fest.  Beautifully built, with horizontal theme answers symmetrical.  For me, some areas filled in in a flash, like that NE to SW sash going down the middle, and, appropriately, it filled in going downhill.  Other parts had bite through oblique cluing and no-knows, satisfying my brain’s workout ethic.

Well, if a puzzle leaves me happy and satisfied, as this one did, it’s more than done its job.  

Thank you, Paul!  I know I will light up when I see your name atop a new puzzle, and I'll be eager to see what you’ve come up with next.

I knew we had some answers that turned corners, hinted at with the title, which I figured out with BLUEDENIM. But I didn't actually get the trick until CAMPFIRES AND SANSSERIF. OMG, the down word works as an up word, too! Brilliant.

Well done!

My youngest has just recovered from an horrific bout of tonsillitis. It didn’t affect his ADENOIDs, but was deeply unpleasant and painful. When I was a kid, a thousand years ago, it was the medical fashion to remove both sets of lymph nodes if you had more than one bout of tonsillitis. They no longer do, meaning that adults now get nasty attacks, like my 23 year old, who needed two lots of antibiotics and three weeks off work. Not sure what changed.

Today, in these comments, my eye landed on a supreme pet peeve of mine: the misuse of the adverb “awhile” when the noun phrase “a while” is the appropriate wording. I thought this might be a nice tip, especially for those whose first language is not English. I hope no one minds my compulsion to bring this up.

I've been amusing myself with the much vex't PAPAW / PAWPAW distinction. The OED citations favours the former until the middle of the nineteenth century, and then make a patchy transition to the latter. You can search in vain for PAWPAW in the 1889 edition of John Lindley's magisterial "Treasury of Botany", for instance, but will find both genera of fruit tree mentioned (albeit briefly) under PAPAW: https://archive.org/details/dli.ernet.240882/page/843/mode/2up But most amusing is yet another illustration of Merriam-Webster's tendency to scrape the internet for uncurated citations. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/papaw While listing PAPAW as "less common spelling of PAWPAW" (go to the page to hear the different pronunciations of the two different spellings), they go on to cite: "His papaw worked on cars his whole life, and East Tennessee teenager Brayden Carroll figured a mechanics job would give him stability and a regular paycheck for a long time."

AMINO bothered me a bit because when I learned organic chemistry a "group" was a set of compounds that had one reactive site bound to several possible carbon backbones.

For example, a compound like R-NH2, was a amine, where R is some combination of carbon and hydrogen.  Likewise, a compound like R-CO-OH is an acid.

But an "amino group" a -CO-OH bound to a carbon which is also bound to an -NH2 group and is called an amino acid.  The simplest is glycine which is HO-OC-CH2-NH2.

Rob, The clue *is* capitalized -- [Old-fashioned ...] -- but the drink name may not need to be. And if you object to the hyphen, which may or may not have been wordplay, please note (as I did): The recipe for the old fashioned dates to the early 1800s, though not by that name. The term "old-fashioned cocktails" dates to 1880, and recipes by that name appear in cocktail books of the late 1880s and 1890s, with Proulx (1888) of Chicago the earliest known. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_fashioned_(cocktail) The rabbit holes down which we disappear...

Jane,

1. Spend (more of) your solving time doing Monday puzzles from the archive (2000-present). You should get more of the answers from the clues and crosses, and you'll start to learn some "crossword-ese" in the process. When you're comfortable with Mondays, try Tuesdays. Rinse and repeat.

2. In the meantime, feel free to look up anything you want, or read the column and comments for help.

@Jane

Nothing wrong with getting help IMO.  The more crosswords you complete with some help, the less you will need help in the future.  Personally after a 3+ year streak I still get help, and I look at it as an opportunity to learn about new things. TIL what a ‘sweeper kicker’ is.

@Jane Keep at it...I started younger than that and for the first few years it was a slog....Lots of open spaces in the puzzle i had never heard of.

THEN at some point you'll just recognize the name of that European river...or that director who was involved in the HUAC...or remember that video game system from 1990.

They tend to be harder over the week...Monday to Friday...by Friday or Saturday there tend to be words which take up the whole line....Thursdays tend to have a trick like a rebus or something else buried in them.

You'll get good at mondays first...and it'll just grow from there.

@Jane 

Read a little about stuff that doesn’t generally interest you. I get the Morning newsletter from the NYT and almost always read all of it, including the sports and arts stuff that isn’t relevant to me. I love music and movies, but the odds of me seeing a Broadway show are pretty slim. 

The more you solve, the better you will get at interpreting the wordplay in the clues. I enjoy American-style crosswords much more than cryptics because every square is checked, which gives me a fighting chance with the answers I can’t easily get. 

Good luck and have fun!
@Jane, I started crosswording by working them together with my mom. She knew the old stuff and I picked it up from her. It expanded my mind, and it gave us something fun and worthwhile to talk about.

@Jane 

You are off to a great start by asking for advice!  I applaud you!  (Plus, anyone who uses nigh so casually seems to be destined for crossword greatness.)

I'll second the advice of those who already answered and add that if you come across something you just don't get, ask us. I guarantee someone will be able to explain. 

I've been at this nigh 18 months and am happy to see my improvements but also know I've a long way to go. Stay humble and open to all there is to be learned... even things like regionalisms and what not. Living in the Midwest all my life, I'd never heard of ACELA before, as one example. Now I plop it right in.  

I've learned to challenge so many of my assumptions along the way.... and learned that so many answers that might make perfect sense, just aren't right in this puzzle. If the crosses aren't serving you, time to get rid of that seemingly perfect answer. 

Also, even if you don't know something, it can often be discerned through familiar spelling and name conventions, so you can often rely on your familiarity with language to get an unknown crossing. 

It takes time to grow an old friend and it takes time to develop strong crossword muscles. Both are worth it!

Various well-known people in the UK are commonly described as having "adenoidal voices"---presenter Melvyn Bragg, politician Ed Miliband, comedian Frank Skinner, all spring to mind. (Miliband was recently reported to have had an adenoidectomy for his sleep apnoea.)

Yes, it's odd to clue ODE to Catullus--he would have just referred to his poems as "carmina"--which basically means "songs"--and so do we, unless we're being more specific as to meter or form ("hendecasyllabics," "elegiac couplets.")
But then again, Horace referred to his lyric poems as "carmina" as well, which we usually translate as "odes." So that doesn't help much.

And forget that whole notion of "song of praise," unless you consider bath-house pick-pockets, freeloading dinner-guests, and people who borrow books and don't return them as worthy of praise.

Not to mention the dead sparrows.

@Diana, did you read the Wordplay column? When I reach that point of frustration, I read the column. First I look at tricky clues (though I find that usually the chosen ones aren't the ones that stymie me!); sometimes filling in one or two answers gets me going. If that doesn't help, then I read about the theme, if the puzzle has one. If it is themeless, you can move on to the answer key.

That said, there's no shame in giving up sometimes! If you're not enjoying it, and it's eluding you, it's just one of those days. Let it go and move on! And tomorrow is Monday, which is likely to restore your confidence.
